channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fatal Shootings at Cafe and Near Synagogue in Copenhagen
item.description: After a gunman killed a man at a cafe event in Denmark featuring an artist who has threatened for caricaturing the Prophet Muhammad, another person was shot dead near a synagogue Saturday. But the police said it was unclear if the episodes were related.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Police officers patrolled central Copenhagen, Denmark, after shots were fired near a synagogue on Saturday.

item.title: Sierra Leone Loses Track of Millions in Ebola Funds
item.description: A report by the country’s national auditor says government ministers lost track of more than $3 million in internal emergency funds to fight the virus.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Raw Eggs and No Husband Since ’38 Keep Her Young at 115
item.description: Emma Morano has survived two world wars, and the hardship of their aftermath; years of domestic terrorism, then years of economic prosperity.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emma Morano in her home in Verbania, Italy. She is the oldest person in Europe, and the fifth oldest in the world.

item.title: Delhi Wakes Up to an Air Pollution Problem It Cannot Ignore
item.description: While Beijing’s air quality has generated more headlines worldwide, scientists say New Delhi’s air is often significantly worse, but only now are residents turning to surgical masks and air purifiers.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Smog enveloped the outskirts of New Delhi in November. While Beijing’s air quality has made more headlines worldwide, scientists say New Delhi’s air is often significantly worse.

item.title: India Blocked an Activist From Traveling to Britain
item.description: A Greenpeace India activist was stopped from boarding a flight to Britain in January, where she was scheduled to brief members of Parliament on the effect of mining on indigenous communities in central India.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Trial on War Crimes Is Set for Ex-President of Chad
item.description: Hissène Habré, who led the country from 1982 to 1990, is being prosecuted abroad after a 19-month investigation into the deaths of thousands.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Canadian Police Say They Foiled a Plot by 3 Suspects to Kill People at a Halifax Mall
item.description: One suspect is said to have fatally shot himself on Friday, and two have been charged with conspiracy to commit murder.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ukraine Cease-Fire Goes Into Effect, but Rebel Leader in Key Town Repudiates Accord
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko ordered forces to cease their fire in the east, but a rebel leader said the accord did not apply to the contested community of Debaltseve.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Ukrainian government soldiers outside Debaltseve, the target of an offensive by rebels.

item.title: Clashes Continue in Iraq Near Base of U.S. Troops
item.description: Iraqi soldiers and militants of the Islamic State group clashed again over the weekend in a Iraqi town that has changed hands several times near a military base where American troops are providing training.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: 1 Dead in Copenhagen Cafe Shooting in 'Likely' Terror Attack
item.description: At least one gunman opened fire Saturday on a Copenhagen cafe, killing one man in what authorities called a likely terror attack during a free speech event organized by an artist who had caricatured the Prophet Muhammad.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Mathias Oegendal/Scanpix Denmark, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Bullet holes in the window and door of a cafe after shots were fired Saturday during a meeting about art, blasphemy and free speech in Copenhagen.

item.title: In Spanish Abuse Scandal, a More Open Vatican
item.description: The case, which includes allegations of a sex ring and a cover-up involving as many as 10 priests, has become one of the most serious abuse scandals to emerge under Pope Francis.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Granada’s archbishop, Francisco Javier Martínez Fernández, met with Pope Francis in Rome last month and was told to face up to the problems within his diocese.

item.title: Bank Hackers Steal Millions via Malware
item.description: A report by a Russian cybersecurity firm says a global gang of thieves penetrated banking systems to steal millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: “The goal was to mimic their activities,” said Sergey Golovanov of Kaspersky, about how the thieves targeted bank employees.

item.title: Islamic State Sprouting Limbs Beyond Its Base
item.description: The Islamic State is expanding beyond its base in Syria and Iraq to establish militant affiliates in Afghanistan, Algeria, Egypt and Libya, raising the prospect of a new global war on terror.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State, to which a broad array of fighters are swearing allegiance.

item.title: Open Source: Sifting Ukrainian Fact From Ukrainian Fiction
item.description: Photographs provided to Senator James Inhofe by Ukrainian officials as proof of Russian involvement in Ukraine were taken during the 2008 Georgia war.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Polio Team Attacked in Pakistan
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack by gunmen Saturday, which left a driver dead and a health care worker wounded.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Ferry Captain Is Convicted in Hong Kong
item.description: The captain of another vessel involved in a 2012 maritime disaster, Hong Kong’s worst in decades, was acquitted of manslaughter Saturday but convicted on a lesser charge.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Canada: Attack Plot Is Foiled, Police Say
item.description: The police said Friday that they had disrupted a plot by four people to kill a “large number of individual citizens” in the Halifax area of Nova Scotia.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Mexico: At Least 16 Killed in Collision
item.description: At least 16 people were killed and 30 injured in a collision between a freight train and a bus on a highway in northern Mexico on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Assia Djebar, Novelist Who Wrote About Oppression of Arab Women, Dies at 78
item.description: Ms. Djebar, frequently mentioned as a contender for the Nobel Prize in Literature, often focused on gender inequality.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Assia Djebar at the Académie Française in Paris in 2006.

item.title: CCTV, China’s Propaganda Tool, Finds Itself at Center of Antigraft Drive
item.description: An inquiry into corruption at CCTV has shaken up the nation’s most influential news organization, with reports involving a seamy mix of celebrities, sex and bribery.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Wang Qinglei, a former producer who worked at China Central Television, or CCTV, from 2003 until he was fired in 2013 for publicly denouncing propaganda on the network, at his new office in Beijing.
